Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides three years of funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "New Mexico Analysis Seminar 2014-2016," the next meeting of which will take place April 5-6, 2014, on the campus of the University of New Mexico.

The New Mexico Analysis Seminar is an annual regional conference serving the US Southwest that alternates venues between the University of New Mexico and New Mexico State University. The themes of the meetings scheduled for the period covered by this award are the following: harmonic analysis and spectral theory, with principal lecturer Sasha Volberg and with a special afternoon session honoring the contributions of Cora Sadosky to the discipline and featuring talks by Jill Pipher, Sergei Treil, and Svitlana Mayboroda (2014, Albuquerque); dispersive partial differential equations, with principal lecturer Monica Visan (2015, Las Cruces); partial differential equations and harmonic analysis, with principal lecturer Chris Sogge (2016, Albuquerque). The conference format provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF award was used to fund 4 events: the 2014, the 2015, and the 2016 "New Mexico Analysis Seminars", and the 2014 "Afternoon in Honor of Cora Sadosky" (a female mathematician who died in December 2010).  The 2014 and 2016 events were held in Albuquerque, NM, the 2015 event was held in Las Cruces, NM. The 2014 events were held prior to a meeting of the American Mathematical Society.

The conferences featured 10 invited speakers, 3 of them women, 3 of Hispanic origin, who are world renown experts in their areas and excellent communicators. The topics of the minicourses and lectures spanned a wide array of topics in mathematical analysis undestood in a broad sense. There were 102 contributed talks: 23% given by students, 40% by postdocs/jr faculty, 21% women, 18% Hispanic/African origin. There were a total of 196 participants: 38% students, 26% postdocs/jr faculty, 22% women, 13% Hispanic/African origin, 25% Asian origin.  The stated goal of offering a platform to junior participants and to a diverse group of mathematicians was met.

The conferences were an excellent opportunity for students in New Mexico to participate in an international event. There were participants from 15 different countries, on average from 15 states and 32 different institutions. It was also an opportunity to strengthen ties between the faculty at The University of New Mexico and New Mexico State University. In May 2017,  a follow up CBMS-NSF conference will be held in Las Cruces with Anna Gilbert as the main lecturer, this event will be preceeded by a one day 16th New Mexico Analysis Seminar.

Two volumes, one already published, the other in press, honoring Cora Sadosky were produced as a result of the "Afternoon" in her honor. There are articles and remembrances by 55 different authors from the US, Canada,  Mexico,  France, Spain, Taiwan, Korea, Brazil, Israel, and Venezuela. The volumes are among the first appearing in the new AWM-Springer Series (AWM stands for American Women in Mathematics).
